What did Mrs. Amanda Newberg say?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Amanda Newberg
Address: Hyas, Sask.
Birthplace: Cokato, Minnesota, USA

Mrs. Lee Westerlund
Hyas, Sask.
Cokato, Minnesota, USA

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

1. What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1905
2. Where did you set up housekeeping? Plateau Post Office - Ulm - Hyas
3. Where had you been living before that? Cokato, Minnesota
4. For how many people did you prepare meals? 4-6
5. How far was it to your nearest store? Canora - 25 miles
6. How often could a visit be made to the store? Hauled grain here by oxen
7. What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Flour, salt, sugar, rice, yeast, oatmeal, green coffee

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

1. What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Fire Roses
2. In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
3. What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
4. How much did you use Graham flour? No
5. Whole wheat flour? No
6. Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 25 miles, what year? 1912
7. What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
8. What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? No, whole wheat? No, Farine? No
9. Other? No
10. Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

How did you grind it?

Poukabors ground flour for these pioneers in 1912. This was white but dark. This Poukabors are the ones Leo by "Verlein" that later moved to B.C. Are the troublesome Sons of Freedom there at present.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? First year bought milk from Rancher, mostly sourced at times. Second year men put up hay for same Rancher earned a few each.
Butter? .......... None
Eggs? .......... None
What was the price of butter? .......... 15¢
Did you keep eggs for winter? .......... Yes
Hot? .......... No
Was this as soon as we had chickens anyway?
Did you make butter? .......... Yes
Cheese? .......... Yes
What kind of cheese? .......... M.A.R.S. & White milk + Remnet.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? .......... Beef & Pork
How did you get fresh meat? .......... Butcher or own
How often did you get fresh meat? .......... Twice a year
How did you preserve meat? .......... Salted
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? .......... No
If so what year was it organized? .......... 1920
Did you use game? .......... Yes
What kinds? .......... Rabbit, Pheasant, Deer
For how long? .......... 1920
What part did fish play in the family diet? .......... Christmas Treat
Was the fish fresh, curst, or canned? .......... Curst
Kinds? .......... Lutefisk, Shipped in

Any trees left are used as shelters.

Last five years have turned to use of coal and oil.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**1945 - Winter**

**Breakfast:** Pancakes - Syrup - (no butter)

**Dinner:** Potatoes - Pork - Bread - Tea. (Never vegetables)

**Supper:** Milk porridge + herring. (favourite)

**Family:** 3 adults - 2 children. Age 2 yrs - 2 mo.

This was before gardens could be planted.

---

**Venison Roast**

**Potatoes**

**Apple (dried) pie**

**Cake - Cookies - Bread - Coffee.**

*Never to starvation but had many very meager meals.*

1945 - Winter:
Breakfast - Pancakes - Syrup - (no butter)
Dinner - Potatoes - Pork - Bread - Tea (with milk)
Supper - Milk porridge + herrings (favorite)

Family 3 adults - 2 children
Age: Drew - 2 mo.

This was before gardens could be planted.
